On Oracle Cloud Machine, the remote storage is the specified NFS storage disk.

notes.description: Free-form text that provides additional information about the backup.

size.description: Size of the backup, in MBs. For example: 1011.4MB (backup complete) or Unknown (backup in-progress).

sizeInBytes.description: Size of the backup, in Bytes.

status.description: Status of the backup. Valid values include: Completed, Failed, Deleted, Backup In Progress, Upload In Progress, Download In Progress, Restore In Progress, or Delete In Progress.

storageContainer.description:
This atttribute is only available on Oracle Public Cloud.

Where service instance backups are stored.

archivedownload-request.description: The request body defines the details of the archive or download backup request.

local.description:
Flag that specifies whether the backup is to be downloaded and stored locally in block storage on the Administration Server (true), or archived and stored remotely (false).

On Oracle Public Cloud, the remote storage is the specified Oracle Storage Cloud Service container.

On Oracle Cloud Machine, the remote storage is the specified NFS storage disk.

deletebackup-request.description: The request body defines the details of the delete backup request. You must specify at least one attribute.

backupId.description: ID of the backup that you want to delete. To retrieve the backup ID, see View All Backups.

backupIdList.description: List of backup IDs that you want to delete. To retrieve the backup IDs, see View All Backups. If the list contains the ID for a full backup, all of its related (non-deleted) incremental backups must be included the list. Use the ?includeLinkedDetails query parameter to retrieve related backups for a backup as described in View a Backup.

deletebackup-response.description: The response body contains information about the delete backup (asynchronous) operation.

job_id.description: Job ID for the delete backup (asynchronous) operation.

operationName.description: Name of operation performed. Set to: delete-backup or delete-backups when deleting a list.

target_uri.description: URI of the delete backup (asynchronous) resource.

archivedownload-response.description: The response body contains information about the archive or download backup operation.

job_id.description: Job ID for the archive or download backup operation.

operationName.description: Name of operation performed. Set to: move-backup.

target_uri.description: URI of the archive or download backup resource.

viewdeleted-response.description: The response body contains information about a backup deleted synchronously or asynchronously, or a list of backups deleted asynchronously.

delete-backup.description: Groups information about a deleted backup.

delete-backups.description: Groups information about a list of backups deleted asynchronously.

viewalldeleted-response.description: The response body contains information about all deleted backups.

completeDate.description: Date and time the delete backup operation completed.

jobId.description: Job ID for the delete backup operation.

operation.description: Type of operation that was executed. Set to delete.

startDate.description: Date and time the delete backup operation started.

status.description: Status of the delete backup operation. Valid values include: Completed, Failed, Deleted, or Delete In Progress.

statusDetails.description: History of system messages. Each message is separated by an ellipses {...}.

backupStartDate.description: Date and time that the backup started.

databaseIncluded.description:
Flag that specifies whether a database backup was performed as part of the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance backup operation. This attribute is only applicable to Oracle Public Cloud. If false, a database backup was not performed. If true, a database backup was performed.

On Oracle Cloud Machine, the value is always false.

dbTag.description:
An RMAN tag or a timestamp. This attribute is only applicable to Oracle Public Cloud.

The attribute is included only if a database backup was performed as part of the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance backup. When the associated Database Cloud Service database deployment is hosting a single-instance database, the attribute value is the RMAN tag that identifies the specific database files backed up. When the associated Database Cloud Service database deployment is hosting an Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) database, the attribute value is the timestamp of the database backup.

deletedOnDate.description: Date and time that the backup deletion completed.

expirationDate.description: Date and time that the backup is deleted automatically from storage. If the value is null, the backup is retained indefinitely or until you manually delete it. (Value is null when keepForever was set to true for an on-demand backup.)

full.description: Flag that specifies whether this was a full (true) or incremental (false) backup.

initiatedBy.description: User account that initiated the operation. Value is scheduled for scheduled automated operations.

jobId.description: Job ID for the delete backup operation.

local.description:
Flag that specifies whether the backup is downloaded and stored locally in block storage on the Administration Server (true), or archived and stored remotely (false).

On Oracle Public Cloud, the remote storage is the specified Oracle Storage Cloud Service container.

On Oracle Cloud Machine, the remote storage is the specified NFS storage disk.

localCopy.description:
Flag that specifies whether the local copy of a backup is maintained for a backup that has been uploaded to remote storage.

On Oracle Public Cloud, the remote storage is the specified Oracle Storage Cloud Service container.

On Oracle Cloud Machine, the remote storage is the specified NFS storage disk.

notes.description: Free-form text that provides additional information about the backup.

size.description: Size of the backup, in MBs.

sizeInBytes.description: Size of the backup, in Bytes.

status.description: Status of the backup. Valid value is Deleted.

storageContainer.description:
This atttribute is only available on Oracle Public Cloud.

Where service instance backups are stored.

restoration-postrequest.description: The request body defines the details of the restoration request.

backupId.description: Backup ID. To retrieve the backup ID, see View All Backups.

forceScaleIn.description:
Flag that specifies whether to automatically scale in the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance if there are Managed Servers configured that are not included in the backup being restored. This value defaults to false, indicating that the service instance should not be scaled in automatically.

If this flag is set to false and the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance has Managed Servers configured that are not included in the backup being restored, the operation fails and the following error message is returned:

JAAS-BR-105: Unable to restore configuration data for managed servers that are not part of the backup. The affected managedsServers are: [managedserver_x, managedserver_y]. Scale in the service instance to remove these managed servers' nodes and then try to restore the service instance again..

notes.description: Free-form text to provide additional information about the restoration operation.

pauseOTD.description:
Flag that specifies whether to pause the load balancer during the restoration process. This value defaults to false.

If set to true, the load balancer is paused and stops forwarding requests to the Managed Servers in the service instance during the restoration process, and responds with an HTTP 503 status code to client requests. After the restoration process completes, the load balancer is restarted.

If pause or restart of the load balancer fails, for example, because the load balancer Administration Server is not available, the restoration process proceeds. The restoration process will fail, however, if the load balancer health check fails.

You should not rely on this feature if any manual tasks are required to be performed once the restoration completes. On Oracle Public Cloud, see Returning an Oracle Java Cloud Service Instance to Service After Restoration from a Backup in Using Oracle Java Cloud Service for more information. On Oracle Cloud Machine, see Returning an Oracle Java Cloud Service Instance to Service After Restoration from a Backup in Using Oracle Java Cloud Service on OPCM.

Note: This flag is valid only if the load balancer is enabled.

resetBinaries.description:
Flag that specifies whether to reset the Oracle WebLogic Server and the JDK software to the versions that correspond to the official patch set update (PSU) level of the software that Oracle Java Cloud Service is currently running. This value defaults to false, indicating that the binary files should not be replaced.

Note: To restore software to an older version, initiate a roll back of the appropriate patch.

restoreConfig.description: Flag that specifies configuration data is restored. This value defaults to true. false is not supported.

restoration-response.description: The response body defines the details of the restoration operation.

operationName.description: Operation performed. This value is set to restore-backup.

job_id.description: Job ID for the restoration operation. You can use the job ID to view the status of the restoration operation, as described in View the Status of a Restoration Operation.

viewallrestorations-response.description: The response body contains the details of the restoration operations.

restoreInProgress.description: Groups details of a restoration operation currently in progress, if any.

backupDate.description: Date and time of the backup.

configDataIncluded.description: Flag that specifies configuration data was restored (true).

databaseIncluded.description: This attribute is only applicable to Oracle Public Cloud. Flag that specifies the database files for the associated Database Cloud Service database deployment were not included in the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance restoration operation (false). If a database backup was performed, the database files must be restored manually.

jobId.description: Job ID for the restore operation.

notes.description: Free-form text that provides additional information about the restoration operation.

otdIncluded.description: Flag that specifies whether the load balancer was restored (true). If OTD is not provisioned or was not provisioned at the time of the backup, the value is false.

recoveryCompleteDate.description: Date and time that the restoration operation completed. This information is not displayed for restorations that are still in progress.

recoveryStartDate.description: Date and time that the restoration operation started.

restoreBinariesType.description:
Type of binary restoration, whether binary restoration was invoked explicitly (resetBinaries is true) or as part of a patch rollback. Valid values include: reset or rollback.

If staticDataIncluded is true, the exact static restore type is displayed.

staticDataIncluded.description: Flag that specifies the static binary files were not included (false) or included (true) in the restoration operation.

status.description: Status of the operation. Valid values include: Completed, Failed, or In Progress.

statusDetails.description: History of system messages. Each message is separated by an ellipses (...).

affectedServer.description: Name of the Managed Server or load balancer impacted by the operation. This attribute is omitted if the operation does not impact a Managed Server or load balancer.

endDate.description: Date and time the operation completed. If the operation is still in progress or if it failed, this attribute is omitted.

hostName.description: Host name of the Managed Server or load balancer.  This attribute is omitted if the operation does not impact a Managed Server or load balancer.

id.description: ID of the operation. You can use the operation ID to check its status, as described in View the Status of a Server Operation by Operation ID.

inProgress.description: Flag that specifies whether the server operation is in progress.

jobId.description:
Job ID for the server operation. You can use the job ID to check its status, as described in View the Status of a Server Operation by Job ID.

Note:This value may be set to No Job Submitted temporarily, just prior to being submitted for processing.

operationType.description: Type of operation. For example: SCALE_IN, SCALE_OUT, START_VM, STOP_VM, START_SERVICE, STOP_SERVICE, and so on.

serviceId.description: ID of the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance.

startDate.description: Date and time the operation started.

status.description: Status of the operation. Example status messages include: Preparing for scaling, Scaling completed, Verifying the scaled WebLogic Server, Scaling operation failed, SUCCEED, and FAILED.

actLog.description: Groups the activities defined in the log.

endDate.description: Date and time the operation ended.

hostName.description: Host name of the server or load balancer.

identityDomainId.description:
Identity domain ID for the Oracle Java Cloud Service account (on Oracle Public Cloud).

Tenant name for the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance (on Oracle Cloud Machine).

jobId.description:
Job ID for the operation.

Note: This value may be set to No Job Submitted temporarily, just prior to being submitted for processing.

operationType.description: Operation type. For example: SCALE_IN, SCALE_OUT, START_VM, STOP_VM, START_SERVICE, STOP_SERVICE, and so on.

serverName.description: Name of the server or load balancer.

serverType.description: Type of server, such as WLS or OTD.

serviceId.description: ID of the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance.

serviceName.description: Name of the Oracle Java Cloud Service instance.

startDate.description: Date and time the operation started.

status.description: Final status of the operation. Example status messages include: NEW, RUNNING, SUCCEED, and FAILED.

activityDate.description: Date and time the activity was logged.

activityMessageId.description: ID of an individual activity message.

stepName.description: Status of the operation at the time that the activity was logged. Example status messages include: NEW, RUNNING, SUCCEED, and FAILED.

servers.description: Groups details of servers defined for the service instance.

serverInProgress.description: Group details of a server creation currently in progress, if any.

clusterName.description: Name of the cluster to which the Managed Server belongs.

creationDate.description: Date and time the server was created.

isAdmin.description: Flag that specifies whether this Managed Server is also the Administration Server.

jobId.description: Job ID for a scale operation.

nodeType.description: Type of node. For example, WLS or DG.

reservedIp.description: This attribute is only available on Oracle Cloud Machine. It is no longer in use.

reservedIpAddress.description:
This attribute is only available on Oracle Public Cloud. It is displayed only when the service instance uses an Oracle Exadata database.

IP address for the IP reservation that is assigned to the Managed Server.

reservedIpName.description:
This attribute is only available on Oracle Public Cloud. It is displayed only when the service instance uses an Oracle Exadata database.

Name of the IP reservation that is assigned to the Managed Server.

shape.description:
Compute shape of the server.

On Oracle Public Cloud, see About Machine Images and Shapes in Using Oracle Compute Cloud Service (for PaaS).

status.description: Status of the operation. For example, Ready.

storageAllocated.description: Amount of allocated storage in MBs.

scale-response.description: The response body contains information about the scale operation.

details.description: Groups the details of the scale operation.

jobId.description: Job ID for the scale operation.

message.description: System message that describes the operation. For example: scaleup.job.submitted

status.description: Status of the operation. When first initiated, the status is set to New. The status may transition to one of the following values: Completed and Cannot Complete.

additionalStorage.description: Amount of gigabytes (GBs) that you want to increase block storage. You can specify the storage volume using the scalingVolume attribute. If no storage volume is specified, a new storage volume is created.

ignoreManagedServerHeapError.description:
Flag that indicates whether to ignore Managed Server heap validation (true) or perform heap validation (false) before a scale down request is accepted. Default is false.

When the flag is not set or is false, heap validation is performed before scaling. If a validation error is not generated, the Managed Server JVM is restarted with the new shape after scaling down.

When the flag is true, heap validation is not performed. Before you set the flag to true, make sure the -Xms value is low enough for the Managed Server JVM to restart on the new shape after scaling down. The -Xms value should be lower than one-fourth the size of the memory associated with the shape. Use the WebLogic Server Administration Console to edit the value in the server start arguments, if necessary.

scalingVolume.description:
Storage volume to which you want to add block storage. This attribute is valid only if you specify the additionalStorage attribute in your request. If not specified, a new storage volume is created.

Valid values include:

  • backup - Adds block storage to the backup storage volume. This is valid when scaling the Administration Server node only.
  • domains - Adds block storage to the domain home storage volume.
  • middleware - Adds block storage to the Oracle Fusion Middleware home storage volume.

shape.description:
Desired compute shape.

This attribute is required. If you do not want to change the compute shape, set this value to match the current compute shape.

Valid shapes include:

  • oc3: 1 OCPU, 7.5 GB memory
  • oc4: 2 OCPUs, 15 GB memory
  • oc5: 4 OCPUs, 30 GB memory
  • oc6: 8 OCPUs, 60 GB memory
  • oc7: 16 OCPUs, 120 GB memory
  • oc1m: 1 OCPU, 15 GB memory
  • oc2m: 2 OCPUs, 30 GB memory
  • oc3m: 4 OCPUs, 60 GB memory
  • oc4m: 8 OCPUs, 120 GB memory
  • oc5m: 16 OCPUs, 240 GB memory

On Oracle Public Cloud, see About Machine Images and Shapes in Using Oracle Compute Cloud Service (for PaaS) for more information about shapes.

scalenode-response.description: The response body contains information about the scale operation on a node.

details.description: Groups the details of the scale operation.

jobId.description: Job ID for the scale operation.

message.description: System message that describes the operation. For example: scaleup.job.submitted

status.description: Status of the operation. When first initiated, the status is set to New. The status may transition to one of the following values: Completed and Cannot Complete.

autoscalingpolicy-response.description: The response body contains the auto scaling policy details when creating, updating, or viewing the policy.

description.description: Description of the auto scaling policy.

name.description: Name of the auto scaling policy. The default name is the service instance name.

policies.description: Groups details about the auto scaling policy.

startTime.description: Date and time the auto scaling policy was created or updated.

status.description: State of the auto scaling policy.

version.description: Version of the auto scaling policy.

description.description: Description of the auto scaling policy.

name.description: Name of the auto scaling policy. If no name is specified, the default name is the service instance name.

policies.description: Groups details about the auto scaling policy.

alarm.description: Groups the conditions for a rule to trigger an alarm.

breachedOnInstance.description: Whether auto scaling is to be performed when an alarm rule is breached on all VM instances or on any of the VM instances. Valid values:ALL, ANY

comparisonOperator.description: The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified statistic and threshold values. Valid values: GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold (for scale out), LessThanOrEqualToThreshold (for scale in)

metricName.description: Name of the metric set in the alarm. Only supported value at this time is CPUUtilization.

metricUnit.description: Unit of measurement for the alarm's associated metric. Valid value: percent

sampleCount.description: The consecutive number of times data is compared for the given metric. A valid value is a positive integer in the range of 1 to 24.

sampleFrequency.description: The interval in minutes when data is compared for the given metric. A valid value is a positive integer in the range of 5 to 60.

statistic.description: The statistic to apply to the alarm's associated metric. Valid values: AVG, MIN, MAX

threshold.description: The value against which the given statistic is compared. A valid value is a positive integer in the range of 1 to 100.

coolDownPeriod.description:
The number of minutes after a scaling activity is completed before any further scaling activities can start. A valid value is a positive integer in the range of 30 to 300.

If the alarm is still active after the cool down period, the scaling activity is repeated. The process continues until the alarm is no longer active, or the maximum or minimum cluster size is reached.

maxClusterSize.description: Maximum cluster size supported by the service instance. Required and valid only for a ScaleOut rule.

minClusterSize.description: Minimum cluster size supported by the service instance. Required and valid only for a ScaleIn rule.

operation.description: The scaling operation to perform when the alarm is triggered. Only scale out and scale in are supported at this time. At least one scaling operation must be defined in the policy. Valid values: scaleOut, scaleIn

alarm.description: Groups the conditions for a rule to trigger an alarm.

breachedOnInstance.description: Whether auto scaling is to be performed when an alarm rule is breached on all VM instances or on any of the VM instances. For example: ALL, ANY.

comparisonOperator.description: Arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified statistic and threshold values. For example: GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold, LessThanOrEqualToThreshold

metricName.description: Name of the metric set in the alarm. For example: CPUUtilization

metricUnit.description: Unit of measurement for the alarm's associated metric. For example: percent

sampleCount.description: The consecutive number of times data is compared for the given metric.

sampleFrequency.description: The interval in minutes when data is compared for the given metric.

statistic.description: The statistic to apply to the alarm's associated metric. For example: AVG, MIN, MAX

threshold.description: The value against which the given statistic is compared.

coolDownPeriod.description: The number of minutes after a scaling activity is completed before any further scaling activities can start.

maxClusterSize.description: Maximum cluster size supported by the service instance when scaling out.

minClusterSize.description: Minimum cluster size supported by the service instance when scaling in.

operation.description: The scaling operation to perform when the alarm is triggered. For example: scaleOut, scaleIn

source.description: Name of the alarm attribute that is causing the error. For example: threshold

status.description: Description of the operation status. For example: Bad Request

activites-response.description: The response body contains the events and activities triggered by the auto scaling policy.

items.description: Groups the events triggered by one or more rules defined in the auto scaling policy.

event.description: The event triggered by a rule. For example: CPUUtilization <= 10 percent

operation.description: Name of the operation performed, either scaleIn or scaleOut.

receiveTime.description: Date and time the event was received.

status.description: Status of the event. For example: Scaling succeeded

time.description: Date and time of the activity.
